title: How to Glitter a Photo Frame

steps.headline: Cover your workspace to keep it clean.
steps.description: It's also recommended to place down a smaller sheet of paper to make it easy to pick up and recycle the loose glitter; a printer paper page is ideal, as it can be turned into a funnel to return the glitter to the jar.

steps.headline: Set out the supplies in readiness for working with.
steps.description: The supplies are listed below, under "Things You'll Need".

steps.headline: Prepare the photo frame.
steps.description: Pop out the glass or perspex in the frame, if relevant. This will stop it from getting glitter on it. An alternative is to cover it with newspaper and painter's tape but it's much easier to remove it, if you can.

steps.headline: Lay the wooden photo frame down on the work surface.
steps.description: Position it over the printer page, if using.

steps.headline: Brush or spray glue down one side of the frame.
Sprinkle glitter down this side.
steps.description: Aim for an even covering, avoiding the creation of clumps on any part of the frame.

steps.headline: Repeat for each side.
steps.description: By doing a side at a time, you can take it slowly and ensure a neat and even covering of glitter. If you'd prefer to just add a design on one part of the frame, simply add liquid glue to that part of the frame and sprinkle the glitter there. For example, you could use a stencil, holding it over the portion of the frame where you'd like the design to go, infill with glue, then sprinkle the glitter on. Remove the stencil before it gets stuck to the frame too.

steps.headline: Allow the glitter to fully dry in place.
steps.description: Collect all loose glitter and restore it to the jar by funneling it back in.

steps.headline: Add sealant.
steps.description: Although optional, a sealant will protect the glitter layer and reduces the amount of glitter that will flake off the frame over time. Use a suitable sealant, such as Mod Podge or varnish. Allow it to fully dry before using the frame.

steps.headline: Done.
steps.description: Slide the glass back into the frame, add your photo and tighten the fittings at the back. The glitter frame is now ready to shine on your shelf.

It's also recommended to place down a smaller sheet of paper to make it easy to pick up and recycle the loose glitter; a printer paper page is ideal, as it can be turned into a funnel to return the glitter to the jar. Set out the supplies in readiness for working with. The supplies are listed below, under "Things You'll Need". Prepare the photo frame. Pop out the glass or perspex in the frame, if relevant. This will stop it from getting glitter on it. An alternative is to cover it with newspaper and painter's tape but it's much easier to remove it, if you can. Making The Glitter Photo Frame Lay the wooden photo frame down on the work surface. Position it over the printer page, if using. Brush or spray glue down one side of the frame.  Sprinkle glitter down this side. Aim for an even covering, avoiding the creation of clumps on any part of the frame. Repeat for each side. By doing a side at a time, you can take it slowly and ensure a neat and even covering of glitter. If you'd prefer to just add a design on one part of the frame, simply add liquid glue to that part of the frame and sprinkle the glitter there. For example, you could use a stencil, holding it over the portion of the frame where you'd like the design to go, infill with glue, then sprinkle the glitter on. Remove the stencil before it gets stuck to the frame too. Allow the glitter to fully dry in place. Collect all loose glitter and restore it to the jar by funneling it back in. Add sealant. Although optional, a sealant will protect the glitter layer and reduces the amount of glitter that will flake off the frame over time. Use a suitable sealant, such as Mod Podge or varnish. Allow it to fully dry before using the frame. Done. Slide the glass back into the frame, add your photo and tighten the fittings at the back. The glitter frame is now ready to shine on your shelf.
